screens.headline: Why did I just get assigned the day before earnings?!
screens.text: Real trader mistake that cost $4,000 in one trade. In 7 minutes, you'll learn the 5 costly errors that trap beginners - and how to avoid them all.

screens.headline: Mistake #1: Ignoring Dividend Dates
screens.text: If you sell a covered call and the stock pays a dividend, you might get EARLY ASSIGNMENT the day before the ex-dividend date. The call buyer wants to own the shares to collect the dividend. You lose both the dividend AND your stock - often at the worst time.

cards.definition: Day before this = you must own stock to get dividend
cards.example: Ex-div Sept 15 ‚Üí own by Sept 14 close to get dividend

cards.definition: Getting assigned before expiration (rare but costly)
cards.example: Sold Sep 30 call, assigned Sep 14 for dividend capture

cards.definition: Getting assigned before earnings (stock gaps, you miss move)
cards.example: Stock at $190, your strike $195, gaps to $220 after earnings

screens.question: Your stock pays a $2 dividend on Friday (ex-div date). Your $180 call is worth $6. What might happen?
options: Nothing - you keep the stock and collect the dividend
Early assignment Thursday night - call buyer wants dividend
You owe $2 to the call buyer
screens.explanation_correct: Exactly! Call buyers know the trick: exercise early to capture the $2 dividend. They pay $180 (your strike), collect $2 dividend = net $178. You lose stock + dividend. Solution: close your call before ex-div date!
screens.explanation_wrong: If your call is IN-THE-MONEY before ex-dividend, the buyer will likely exercise early to steal your dividend. Close your position or roll it before the ex-div date to avoid this.

screens.question: Mistake #2: You sold a $200 call on Monday. Earnings are Thursday after market close. Stock is $195. What's the risk?
options: No risk - strike is $200, stock only at $195
If stock gaps to $220 on Friday, you only profit to $200
screens.explanation_correct: Correct! If stock jumps to $220 on great earnings, you sell at $200 (missing $20/share = $2,000 profit). Your call buyer gets all the upside. Lesson: Close covered calls BEFORE major events or sell strikes far OTM.
screens.explanation_wrong: Think about it: Stock gaps from $195 to $220 overnight. Your call is $200 strike. You're assigned at $200, but stock is worth $220. You gave away $2,000!

screens.headline: Mistake #3: Selling Calls on Stocks You Love
screens.text: It's like renting out your dream car. Sure, you make $500/month. But what if the renter totals it? Or doesn't return it? Or you need it for an important trip? Same with stocks: Don't sell covered calls on positions you're emotionally attached to or plan to hold forever. Only do it on stocks you're OK selling.

reveal_sections.label: Dream car = Core long-term holding (AAPL, MSFT you'll hold 10+ years)
Can't get it back = Stock called away at $200, now trading at $300
Emotional regret = Watching 'your' stock 10x after assignment

teaching_points: Check dividend calendar BEFORE selling calls
Close positions before earnings if unsure
Don't panic trade - remember you own the stock

cards.back: ALWAYS check ex-dividend dates. Close calls before ex-div if your call is ITM. Don't let buyers steal your dividend!
Close calls before major earnings OR sell strikes 10%+ OTM. Don't cap your gains right before a gap move.
Don't sell calls on core holdings you love. Only use for 'trading' positions you're OK selling.
Don't panic close when stock drops. You own the stock anyway! Premium is your cushion.
Getting assigned triggers capital gains tax. Track your cost basis. Short-term gains (< 1 year) = higher tax rate.
